review.title: A hidden treasure
review.reviewText:
What an unexpected surprise.  A historic piece of Spain adapted for the modern tourist while maintaining all the mystery and stark charm of a monastery that was the home of 500 monks at its peak.  

Long corridors with nooks and cranies that lead the guests to their adequately furnished, and well heated, large cell ; we visited over wet and chilly days in March,.  To dine in the former monks refectory with the walls  hung with tapesteries and paintings beneath a wooden beamed ceiling, prepared diners for what was a splendid supper offering a range of Spanish specialities and local dishes. 

The courtyards and large vegetable garden encourage the visitor to explore the estate. A place to revisit.

review.title: FAR AWAY HOTEL
review.reviewText:
Unfortunately the ad for the hotel does not mention that it is located 35 miles (48 km) from Cordoba.
Other than that, the hotel is fine
review.negativeRemarks: the internet the ad about the hotel should indicate the distance to Cordoba and also that there is no elevator

review.title: Something a little different to the norm
review.reviewText: We really liked the hotel. You could park for free on all the side roads surrounding the hotel so it is perfect if you are on a driving tour round Andalusia. The decoration is quirky and the place grounds are beautiful. The hotel is a good place to stop off between Cordoba and Seville. We visited in late September and found the actual town it is in, Palma del Rio (approx. 40 min drive to Cordoba) is a quite little town, mainly with local people who don't speak English. There were plenty of good cafes and bars near by and we managed to muddle our way through with virtually no Spanish language skills. The restaurant and bar in the hotel were very quite, and far more expensive than the local places, so we avoided them.
review.positiveRemarks: Quirky decoration and grounds, different to anywhere we have stayed before
review.negativeRemarks: Information on arrival, i.e. WIFI password, details of breakfast/restaurant
review.locationRemarks: There are some sights nearby and Cordoba is ~40 min drive and Seville ~1 hour drive

review.title: Great Monastery Retreat but Still silent order.
review.reviewText: The hotel was fine. They let themselves down in 2 ways. They told me about their secure parking but didn't tell me it cost 10 euros a day. The food was ok but very salty and not up to the promised levels. Nice place though. Lots of ringing bells on a Saturday night.

review.title: pleasant surprise
review.reviewText: Unexpected, relaxed accommodation, LOTS OF ROOM FOR LUGGAGE, quiet, food in the refectory good,helpful with car parking which is quite secure. We did not realise the hotel was 50km from Cordoba that was not a big problem.

review.title: Historic Interest but In Transition
review.reviewText: Located in the market town of Palma del Rio, the hotel is housed in a wonderful old Franciscan monastery, with large rooms, wide staircases, and spacious public spaces, and has a large garden and outdoor pool in the grounds behind it. It has 'good bones' and will make a wonderful lodging when the renovations currently ongoing are finished. They are upgrading the facility to qualify for the Spanish four-star hotel category. This unfortunately marred our stay: the bar was not functioning and an evening meal was by special request only, so it really was operating as a bed and breakfast (not included in the room charge). Breakfast was an ample buffet, however, served in what had been the monastery refectory--a grand space. It is useful also to know Palma del Rio lies an hour's drive from Cordoba, which was the focus of our visit.

review.title: Not a regular hotel
review.reviewText: This is not your regular hotel. You could love it or hate it. The walled gardens are lovely and peaceful and we liked these very much. The long narrow swimming pool is set in grass and orange trees one side and attractive vegetable plots the other. Sounds weird but it works, and you gaze at the old monastery building from the pool recliners. It is hard to say the rooms are attractive although they all have unique and attractive features. The inner facing rooms are downright dismal. We were allocated one. The bed was slightly damp, the mattress sagged in the middle, and the lighting gloomy. There was one small north facing window which passersby peer in through, slight air of mouldiness, all in all rather miserable. Everything changed when the room opposite become free. We asked for a change which was freely given. Our new room had two big windows opening to the outside, to the sun and the scent of orange blossom (we stayed in April). Although the room was still very basic and monastic, it had romance and light and we loved this room. So, great hotel with great character and interest but make sure you get an outside facing room. The building is hundreds of years old and the rooms reflect this. Do not expect modern glitzy surroundings although the bathroom fittings and facilities are all clean and newly fitted. We stayed in April, in the overpowering heat of summer everything may appear quite different.

review.title: Peace and quiet
review.reviewText: We chose this hotel and in fact the area because we wanted to "be" rather than "do". It was certainly perfect for that..... But Breakfast was extremely pricely compared with local bars Though the receptionists spoke fair/adequate English (this is not a place for you if you expect much English) all touristy information, including menus, were only available in Spanish.

review.title: An historic gem
review.reviewText: A relaxing and quiet overnight stay. Food and service of a high standard. The hotel and Expedia went to great lengths to make contact with us in order to return a credit card that had been accidentally left behind. Very grateful, thank you.

review.title: The best place to stay near Cordoba
review.reviewText: a fantastic place to stay; it really lived up to my expectations as the hotel still had a lovely, peaceful feel about it. The whole place was tastefully furnished in keeping with the fact that it had been a monastery. The rooms were beautiful; we had a fantastic bathroom with a double sink made from Spanish ceramics and there were all sorts of nooks and crannies. The cloisters were lovely with antique furniture and pots of geraniums. The lounge was huge; very majestic and the dining room was tastefully decorated with plain white linen cloths and wooden chairs in keeping with the whole atmosphere of the place. I would love to go back again for a longer visit.Superb!!!
